summary: The appellant was charged under sections 148(3)(c) and 152(3) of the Criminal Code for possession without lawful authority and intent to utter, respectively. The charges lacked full particularsâ€”specifically, 'possession without lawful authority' and 'guilty knowledge or intent to utter' were not clearly set out. The court held that while such omissions would invalidate convictions in trials upon information (per Rex v. Harvey), they do not vitiate summary trials provided the accused receives adequate notice of the charges. The court found the appellant had sufficient notice and was clearly guilty on the merits. The appeal was dismissed.
rationaleHighlights: Insufficient particulars in a summary trial do not invalidate a conviction if the accused had adequate notice.
Unlike trials upon information, summary trials allow for procedural flexibility.
The court distinguished Rex v. Harvey due to the summary nature of the trial.
The appellant was found clearly guilty on the merits.
